image.altText: Morrison and Macron at a table in the garden.

props.synopsis: Scott Morrison reveals the covert diplomatic manoeuvres behind the biggest deal of his prime ministership and how he kept it a secret from the man who could torpedo it.

title.children: 'I don't think, I know': The story behind the infamous French sledge about Scott Morrison

image.altText: Rural Fire Service volunteer on a fireground

props.synopsis: Fire authorities warn Victorians to brace for a "catastrophic" fire danger rating today, with parts of the state urged to be ready to evacuate.

title.children: Victoria could be in for its worst day for fire danger since the Black Summer bushfires — here's what you need to know

image.altText: A silhouette of a person in a hoodie over wetlands at sunset.

props.synopsis: Jade has lost four family members to suicide. She is one of hundreds of First Nations people grieving for loved ones as the rate at which Indigenous people taking their own lives continues to rise.

title.children: Jade is one of hundreds of First Nations people grieving for their loved ones amid rising suicide rates

image.altText: A man plays a didgeridoo while people sit on chairs.

props.synopsis: The government's Help to Buy scheme shapes up as the next protracted battle in the Labor-Greens housing wars as Senate Estimates continues in the second week of parliament sittings. Follow live.

title.children: Leaders mark anniversary of Stolen Generations apology as battle looms over Help to Buy scheme

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: PM says we need to 'listen to First Nations people on how to close the gap'

image.altText: A group of people stand before desks covered in paper in large room, facing fowards. One person, Adila Hassim, faces the camera.

props.synopsis: When Adila Hassim represented South Africa in its ICJ case against Israel, she was struck by the overwhelming sense that the courtroom is not a place for women. She's one of many prominent voices now calling for change in the world's highest court.

title.children: In the highest court in the world, which is hearing allegations of genocide against Israel, where are all the women?

image.altText: A young white woman teaching a primary school class

props.synopsis: A reading revolution at a small, disadvantaged public school in regional Victoria could provide the blueprint for turning around alarming literacy rates in Australia's 10,000 primary schools.

title.children: As the 'reading wars' raged, this school made a teaching change. The results were profound

image.altText: Old Taipan helicopters in a warehouse

props.synopsis: A leaked photo of dismantled Taipan helicopters slated for burial has reignited frustrations over a decision not to send the aircraft to Ukraine, but one army association says doing so would have been gifting the nation a "poisoned chalice".

title.children: Leaked photo reveals gutted Taipan helicopters destined for the dirt

image.altText: Commander of the Ukrainian army, Col. Gen. Oleksandr Syrskyi, gives instructions in a shelter in Soledar.

props.synopsis: The success of Ukraine's new military commander-in-chief depends on a good relationship with his president, a supportive Ukrainian parliament, military assistance from the West and political objectives aligning with military realities. It is a daunting predicament, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Ukraine's new military chief faces gargantuan challenges

image.altText: Artist's impression of a five story apartment block.

props.synopsis: Millennials moving to regional towns are part of a "societal shift" and they're not interested in buying big blocks with big backyards. But they do need to live somewhere.

title.children: How high is too high? Small towns fear multi-storey apartment blocks will change them forever

image.altText: Snowtown accomplice Mark Ray Haydon in a car being escorted from court.

props.synopsis: Snowtown accomplice Mark Ray Haydon could be out of prison within weeks if a long-standing parole bid is approved.

title.children: 'Bodies in the barrels' accomplice pushes for early release

image.altText: Picture from the ground looking up at a high-voltage transmission tower, with wind turbines in the background

props.synopsis: With wholesale power prices falling, you would be forgiven for thinking relief from high electricity bills is on the horizon — but the complexities that exist in our power supply industry mean we'll be waiting a while yet, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: Electricity prices are crashing but don't expect cheaper bills anytime soon

image.altText: A swarm of red fire ants.

props.synopsis: The Commonwealth and state governments are doubling down on a half-billion-dollar program that's so far failed to stop the spread of the red imported fire ant.

title.children: The billion-dollar battle to wipe out a deadly pest that is threatening Australia's outdoor lifestyle

image.altText: A close-up of Lisa Wilkinson smiling.

props.synopsis: Lisa Wilkinson continues her fight to have Network Ten pay her legal costs from Bruce Lehrmann's defamation case, while former ACT top prosecutor Shane Drumgold begins a challenge to damning findings about his conduct during Mr Lehrmann's prosecution.

title.children: Lisa Wilkinson back in court to chase Network Ten for legal bills run up during Bruce Lehrmann's defamation case

image.altText: A green park with a bridge and mulch

props.synopsis: The City of Sydney found bonded and friable asbestos at three parks across the inner-city area, near Broadway, Surry Hills and Central Station.

title.children: High risk type of asbestos found in contaminated mulch at a Sydney dog park

image.altText: A middle-aged Chinese man in a black suit standing next to a sign that says 'Build Your Dreams'

props.synopsis: Elon Musk once mocked electric vehicle maker BYD. Now he says Chinese companies like BYD could dominate global car sales. Here's the story of its remarkable rise.

title.children: How a mobile phone battery maker beat Tesla to become the world's largest EV company

image.altText: Two electric VW cars rest in front of the Sydney Harbour Bridge.

props.synopsis: As car executives meet to discuss the government's new Vehicle Efficiency Standard, Hyundai, Volkswagen and Kia are among the car brands lining up behind the government's plan to cut car industry emissions.

title.children: Volkswagen, Hyundai lining up in favour of Vehicle Efficiency Standard, as car execs meet for crisis talks

image.altText: The ASX boards in Sydney

props.synopsis: The Australian share market is likely to open slightly higher despite a mixed performance on Wall Street. Meanwhile, the price of bitcoin has surged to $US50,000 for the first time in two years. Follow live.

title.children: ASX to rise, Dow Jones hits record high, bitcoin jumps to $US50,000

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Productivity slump likely to fix itself: RBA
Macquarie profit hurt by weakness in annuity, market-facing businesses

image.altText: An older man in a suit and red, spotted tie, speaks into a microphone on a podium during an address.

props.synopsis: Australia's trade minister says he will raise wine and lobster sanctions when he meets with his Chinese counterpart this month and that if wine tariffs are not removed by the end of March Australia will take China back to the WTO.

title.children: Wine and lobster on the table as trade minister meets with Chinese counterpart to discuss tariffs

image.altText: The WhatsApp app logo is seen on a smartphone.

props.synopsis: The federal government says legislation to combat doxxing will be brought to parliament as soon as possible following the details of Jewish Australians being published online.

title.children: 'Doxxing' could be criminalised after hundreds of Jewish Australians' names and messages published

image.altText: Five Burarra women in shirts and long skirts stand together on a beach in the afternoon sun.

props.synopsis: The NGV commissioned 25 new artworks for its Triennial, including an epic one-of-a-kind weaving from a remote Top End community determined to keep its traditions alive through art.

title.children: Meet the remarkable Arnhem Land women behind Australia's largest woven sculpture

image.altText: father adrian with wife nicole and young children leonardo and luna sit on the sand at a beach

props.synopsis: High housing costs are to blame for the Harbour City losing twice as many people aged 30 to 40 as it gains, amid warnings this group is among the most productive demographic.

title.children: Sydneysiders aged 30 to 40 leaving in droves to avoid 'harder and sad life'

image.altText: A stack of four pancakes on a plate with ice cream and syrup

props.synopsis: The Shrove Tuesday tradition is based on Christians using up all their fats before fasting.

title.children: Some people will observe 'pancake day' today. Here are its religious origins

image.altText: Bananas lined up on shelves at Woolworths

props.synopsis: Bright yellow with blemish-free skin, bananas at major supermarkets tend to look 'perfect", but will a push to sell produce affected by recent tropical cyclones in North Queensland shatter this widespread consumer ideology?

title.children: Cyclone-damaged produce promoted by major supermarket

image.altText: A plane in the sky saying Batik on the side.

props.synopsis: It's had a chequered history with getting international travel off the ground but Canberra Airport executives say a smaller, sustainable approach will keep direct, international flights viable for locals.

title.children: Two carriers are on board for international flights from Canberra, but keeping them could prove a challenge

image.altText: A black and white photo of a group of huskies pulling a sled with two men on it over snow-covered ground

props.synopsis: On February 13, 1954, a group of expeditioners set up camp in Antarctica. Seventy years on, their huskies are no longer there but Australia's presence at Mawson Station remains vital for scientific research on the frozen continent.

title.children: Antarctic expeditioners celebrate Mawson Station's 70th anniversary

image.altText: Cameron McEvoy stands on a podium

props.synopsis: Cameron McEvoy powers to bronze in the 50m butterfly at the world championships in Doha on a night of near misses for the Australian team.

title.children: Cameron McEvoy wins World Championship butterfly bronze

image.altText: A sign for the Youth Court in Adelaide

props.synopsis: Two children remain in custody charged over the alleged stabbing of a boy in Adelaide's northern suburbs.

title.children: Teenagers accused of stabbing 12yo boy in leg denied bail

image.altText: A fire truck outside an Ice Arena venue.

props.synopsis: The number of cases of carbon monoxide exposure at an Adelaide ice skating rink has increased to 42, South Australia's public health chief Nicola Spurrier says.

title.children: Carbon monoxide exposure cases increase to 42 after ice rink exhaust fumes leak

image.altText: Man with dreadlocks at the beach

props.synopsis: Jackson Stacker's decomposing body was found in a paddock with a knife embedded in his chest.

title.children: Inquest hears details of Melbourne man's mysterious death near Byron Bay

image.altText: Fernando Simon Marman hugs a woman around the same age with short hair tightly in a hospital hallway

props.synopsis: Israel launched a special forces operation that has freed two Israeli hostages in Rafah amid air strikes, which local health officials said killed 67 people and wounded dozens in the southern Gaza city.

title.children: Israel rescues two hostages in Rafah, as health officials say 67 people killed by air strikes

image.altText: Police officers secure the area around the building of a shipping company.

props.synopsis: Three people have been fatally shot while at work at a shipping company near Athens.

title.children: Shooting at Greek shipping company kills four, including owner and suspected gunman

image.altText: A montage of pictures of an American football game

props.synopsis: Super Bowl LVIII had just about everything — a sideline stoush between Travis Kelce and Andy Reid, a trick-play touchdown and a crucial blocked extra point. Here are the five quick hits from Las Vegas.

title.children: Super Bowl five quick hits: Kelce shoves his coach and a 49er suffers a shocking sideline injury in overtime thriller

image.altText: A split image of a woman in a dress and in running gear.

props.synopsis: Missing Ballarat woman Samantha Murphy has three children with strong connections in the community and her disappearance has left some children feeling anxious.

title.children: School children left 'nervous' by disappearance of Ballarat mother Samantha Murphy

image.altText: Secretary of the Department of Defence Dennis Richardson speaks at the National Press Club.

props.synopsis: A review has found the former Coalition government awarded contracts for offshore asylum seeker processing to companies with suspected links to arms and drug smuggling, corruption and bribery.

title.children: Home Affairs contracts awarded to companies with suspected links to drugs, firearms and bribery

image.altText: A single firefighter fights a huge fire as it destroys wooden and plastic shelters

props.synopsis: In the Rohingya refugee camps of Cox's Bazar, more than 1 million people are living in worsening conditions. However, the world wasn't watching when tragedy unfolded.

title.children: A massive fire left 7,000 people, including thousands of children, homeless. Australia didn't seem to notice
